member.summary: Returns this transaction snapshot read version.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.GetCommittedVersion
member.summary: Retrieves the database version number at which a given transaction was committed.
member.remarks: CommitAsync() must have been called on this transaction and the resulting task must have completed successfully before this function is callged, or the behavior is undefined. Read-only transactions do not modify the database when committed and will have a committed version of -1. Keep in mind that a transaction which reads keys and then sets them to their current values may be optimized to a read-only transaction.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.SetReadVersion(System.Int64)
member.summary: Sets the snapshot read version used by a transaction. This is not needed in simple cases.
member.param: Read version to use in this transaction
member.remarks: If the given version is too old, subsequent reads will fail with error_code_past_version; if it is too new, subsequent reads may be delayed indefinitely and/or fail with error_code_future_version. If any of Get*() methods have been called on this transaction already, the result is undefined.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.GetAsync(FoundationDB.Client.Slice,System.Boolean,System.Threading.CancellationToken)

Set to true for snapshot reads

Set to true for snapshot reads
Token used to cancel the operation from the outside
member.returns: Task that will return an array of values, or an exception. Each item in the array will contain the value of the key at the same index in , or Slice.Nil if that key does not exist.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.GetRangeAsync(FoundationDB.Client.FdbKeySelector,FoundationDB.Client.FdbKeySelector,FoundationDB.Client.FdbRangeOptions,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Reads all key-value pairs in the database snapshot represented by transaction (potentially limited by Limit, TargetBytes, or Mode) which have a key lexicographically greater than or equal to the key resolved by the begin key selector and lexicographically less than the key resolved by the end key selector.
member.param: key selector defining the beginning of the range
key selector defining the end of the range
Optionnal query options (Limit, TargetBytes, Mode, Reverse, ...)
If streaming mode is FdbStreamingMode.Iterator, this parameter should start at 1 and be incremented by 1 for each successive call while reading this range. In all other cases it is ignored.
Set to true for snapshot reads
Token used to cancel the operation from the outside

The modification affects the actual database only if transaction is later committed with CommitAsync().

Value to be inserted into the database.

member.param: Name of the key whose value is to be mutated.
Parameter with which the atomic operation will mutate the value associated with key_name.
Type of mutation that should be performed on the key

member.summary: Modify the database snapshot represented by this transaction to remove the given key from the database. If the key was not previously present in the database, there is no effect.
member.param: Name of the key to be removed from the database.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.ClearRange(FoundationDB.Client.Slice,FoundationDB.Client.Slice)
member.summary: Modify the database snapshot represented by this transaction to remove all keys (if any) which are lexicographically greater than or equal to the given begin key and lexicographically less than the given end_key. Sets and clears affect the actual database only if transaction is later committed with CommitAsync().
member.param: Name of the key specifying the beginning of the range to clear.
Name of the key specifying the end of the range to clear.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.AddConflictRange(FoundationDB.Client.Slice,FoundationDB.Client.Slice,FoundationDB.Client.FdbConflictRangeType)
member.summary: Adds a conflict range to a transaction without performing the associated read or write.
member.param: Key specifying the beginning of the conflict range. The key is included
Key specifying the end of the conflict range. The key is excluded
One of the FDBConflictRangeType values indicating what type of conflict range is being set.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.Watch(FoundationDB.Client.Slice,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Watch a key for any change in the database.
member.param: Key to watch
CancellationToken used to abort the watch if the caller doesn't want to wait anymore. Note that you can manually cancel the watch by calling Cancel() on the returned FdbWatch instance
member.returns: FdbWatch that can be awaited and will complete when the key has changed in the database, or cancellation occurs. You can call Cancel() at any time if you are not interested in watching the key anymore. You MUST always call Dispose() if the watch completes or is cancelled, to ensure that resources are released properly.
member.remarks: You can directly await an FdbWatch, or obtain a Task<Slice> by reading the property.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.CommitAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Attempts to commit the sets and clears previously applied to the database snapshot represented by this transaction to the actual database. The commit may or may not succeed in particular, if a conflicting transaction previously committed, then the commit must fail in order to preserve transactional isolation. If the commit does succeed, the transaction is durably committed to the database and all subsequently started transactions will observe its effects.
member.param: Token used to cancel the operation from the outside
member.returns: Task that succeeds if the transaction was comitted successfully, or fails if the transaction failed to commit.
member.remarks: As with other client/server databases, in some failure scenarios a client may be unable to determine whether a transaction succeeded. In these cases, CommitAsync() will throw CommitUnknownResult error. The OnErrorAsync() function treats this error as retryable, so retry loops that dont check for CommitUnknownResult could execute the transaction twice. In these cases, you must consider the idempotence of the transaction.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.OnErrorAsync(FoundationDB.Client.FdbError,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Implements the recommended retry and backoff behavior for a transaction. This function knows which of the error codes generated by other query functions represent temporary error conditions and which represent application errors that should be handled by the application. It also implements an exponential backoff strategy to avoid swamping the database cluster with excessive retries when there is a high level of conflict between transactions.
member.param: FdbError code thrown by the previous command
Token used to cancel the operation from the outside
member.returns: Returns a task that completes if the operation can be safely retried, or that rethrows the original exception if the operation is not retryable.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.Reset
member.summary: Reset transaction to its initial state.
member.remarks: This is similar to disposing the transaction and recreating a new one. The only state that persists through a transaction reset is that which is related to the backoff logic used by OnErrorAsync()

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.Cancel
member.summary: Cancels the transaction. All pending or future uses of the transaction will return a TransactionCancelled error code. The transaction can be used again after it is reset.

member.name: P:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.Size
member.summary: Returns the estimated payload size of the transaction (including keys and values)

member.name: P:FoundationDB.Client.Core.IFdbTransactionHandler.IsClosed
member.summary: Checks if this transaction handler is closed

If the transaction has already been completed
If the operation method is called from the Network Thread

member.param: Keys to be looked up in the database
member.returns: Task that will return an array of values, or an exception. Each item in the array will contain the value of the key at the same index in , or Slice.Nil if that key does not exist.

member.summary: Reads all key-value pairs in the database snapshot represented by transaction (potentially limited by Limit, TargetBytes, or Mode) which have a key lexicographically greater than or equal to the key resolved by the begin key selector and lexicographically less than the key resolved by the end key selector.
member.param: key selector defining the beginning of the range
key selector defining the end of the range
Optionnal query options (Limit, TargetBytes, Mode, Reverse, ...)
If streaming mode is FdbStreamingMode.Iterator, this parameter should start at 1 and be incremented by 1 for each successive call while reading this range. In all other cases it is ignored.

member.summary: Create a new range query that will read all key-value pairs in the database snapshot represented by the transaction
member.param: key selector defining the beginning of the range
key selector defining the end of the range
Optionnal query options (Limit, TargetBytes, Mode, Reverse, ...)
member.returns: Range query that, once executed, will return all the key-value pairs matching the providing selector pair

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbReadOnlyTransaction.SetReadVersion(System.Int64)
member.summary: Sets the snapshot read version used by a transaction. This is not needed in simple cases.
member.param: Read version to use in this transaction
member.remarks: If the given version is too old, subsequent reads will fail with error_code_past_version; if it is too new, subsequent reads may be delayed indefinitely and/or fail with error_code_future_version. If any of Get*() methods have been called on this transaction already, the result is undefined.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbReadOnlyTransaction.Cancel
member.summary: Cancels the transaction. All pending or future uses of the transaction will return a TransactionCancelled error code. The transaction can be used again after it is reset.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbReadOnlyTransaction.Reset
member.summary: Reset transaction to its initial state.
member.remarks: This is similar to disposing the transaction and recreating a new one. The only state that persists through a transaction reset is that which is related to the backoff logic used by OnErrorAsync()

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbReadOnlyTransaction.OnErrorAsync(FoundationDB.Client.FdbError)
member.summary:
Implements the recommended retry and backoff behavior for a transaction.
This function knows which of the error codes generated by other query functions represent temporary error conditions and which represent application errors that should be handled by the application. It also implements an exponential backoff strategy to avoid swamping the database cluster with excessive retries when there is a high level of conflict between transactions.
member.param: FdbError code thrown by the previous command
member.returns: Returns a task that completes if the operation can be safely retried, or that rethrows the original exception if the operation is not retryable.

member.name: P:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbReadOnlyTransaction.Timeout
member.summary: Timeout in milliseconds which, when elapsed, will cause the transaction automatically to be cancelled. Valid parameter values are ``[0, INT_MAX]``. If set to 0, will disable all timeouts. All pending and any future uses of the transaction will throw an exception. The transaction can be used again after it is reset.

member.name: P:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbReadOnlyTransaction.RetryLimit
member.summary: Maximum number of retries after which additional calls to onError will throw the most recently seen error code. Valid parameter values are ``[-1, INT_MAX]``. If set to -1, will disable the retry limit.

The modification affects the actual database only if transaction is later committed with CommitAsync().
member.param: Name of the key to be inserted into the database.
Value to be inserted into the database.

member.param: Name of the key whose value is to be mutated.
Parameter with which the atomic operation will mutate the value associated with key_name.
Type of mutation that should be performed on the key

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbTransaction.Clear(FoundationDB.Client.Slice)
member.summary: Modify the database snapshot represented by this transaction to remove the given key from the database. If the key was not previously present in the database, there is no effect.
member.param: Name of the key to be removed from the database.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbTransaction.ClearRange(FoundationDB.Client.Slice,FoundationDB.Client.Slice)
member.summary: Modify the database snapshot represented by this transaction to remove all keys (if any) which are lexicographically greater than or equal to the given begin key and lexicographically less than the given end_key. Sets and clears affect the actual database only if transaction is later committed with CommitAsync().
member.param: Name of the key specifying the beginning of the range to clear.
Name of the key specifying the end of the range to clear.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbTransaction.AddConflictRange(FoundationDB.Client.Slice,FoundationDB.Client.Slice,FoundationDB.Client.FdbConflictRangeType)
member.summary: Adds a conflict range to a transaction without performing the associated read or write.
member.param: Key specifying the beginning of the conflict range. The key is included
Key specifying the end of the conflict range. The key is excluded
One of the FDBConflictRangeType values indicating what type of conflict range is being set.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbTransaction.CommitAsync
member.summary: Attempts to commit the sets and clears previously applied to the database snapshot represented by this transaction to the actual database. The commit may or may not succeed in particular, if a conflicting transaction previously committed, then the commit must fail in order to preserve transactional isolation. If the commit does succeed, the transaction is durably committed to the database and all subsequently started transactions will observe its effects.
member.returns: Task that succeeds if the transaction was comitted successfully, or fails if the transaction failed to commit.
member.remarks: As with other client/server databases, in some failure scenarios a client may be unable to determine whether a transaction succeeded. In these cases, CommitAsync() will throw CommitUnknownResult error. The OnErrorAsync() function treats this error as retryable, so retry loops that dont check for CommitUnknownResult could execute the transaction twice. In these cases, you must consider the idempotence of the transaction.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbTransaction.GetCommittedVersion
member.summary: Retrieves the database version number at which a given transaction was committed.
member.remarks: CommitAsync() must have been called on this transaction and the resulting task must have completed successfully before this function is callged, or the behavior is undefined. Read-only transactions do not modify the database when committed and will have a committed version of -1. Keep in mind that a transaction which reads keys and then sets them to their current values may be optimized to a read-only transaction.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.IFdbTransaction.Watch(FoundationDB.Client.Slice,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Watch a key for any change in the database.
member.param: Key to watch
CancellationToken used to abort the watch if the caller doesn't want to wait anymore. Note that you can manually cancel the watch by calling Cancel() on the returned FdbWatch instance
member.returns: FdbWatch that can be awaited and will complete when the key has changed in the database, or cancellation occurs. You can call Cancel() at any time if you are not interested in watching the key anymore. You MUST always call Dispose() if the watch completes or is cancelled, to ensure that resources are released properly.
member.remarks: You can directly await an FdbWatch, or obtain a Task<Slice> by reading the property.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Fdb.System.GetBoundaryKeysAsync(FoundationDB.Client.IFdbReadOnlyTransaction,FoundationDB.Client.Slice,FoundationDB.Client.Slice)
member.summary: Returns a list of keys k such that <= k < and k is located at the start of a contiguous range stored on a single server
member.param: Transaction to use for the operation
First key (inclusive) of the range to inspect
End key (exclusive) of the range to inspect
member.returns: List of keys that mark the start of a new chunk
member.remarks: This method is not transactional. It will return an answer no older than the Transaction object it is passed, but the returned boundaries are an estimate and may not represent the exact boundary locations at any database version.

member.param: Database to use for the operation
First key (inclusive) of the range to inspect
End key (exclusive) of the range to inspect
Token used to cancel the operation
member.returns: List of keys that mark the start of a new chunk
member.remarks: This method is not transactional. It will return an answer no older than the Database object it is passed, but the returned boundaries are an estimate and may not represent the exact boundary locations at any database version.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.Fdb.System.GetChunksAsync(FoundationDB.Client.IFdbDatabase,FoundationDB.Client.FdbKeyRange,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Split a range of keys into smaller chunks where each chunk represents a contiguous range stored on a single server
member.param: Database to use for the operation
Range of keys to split up into smaller chunks
Token used to cancel the operation
member.returns: List of one or more chunks that constitutes the range, where each chunk represents a contiguous range stored on a single server. If the list contains a single range, that means that the range is small enough to fit inside a single chunk.
member.remarks: This method is not transactional. It will return an answer no older than the Database object it is passed, but the returned ranges are an estimate and may not represent the exact boundary locations at any database version.

member.returns: List of one or more chunks that constitutes the range, where each chunk represents a contiguous range stored on a single server. If the list contains a single range, that means that the range is small enough to fit inside a single chunk.
member.remarks: This method is not transactional. It will return an answer no older than the Database object it is passed, but the returned ranges are an estimate and may not represent the exact boundary locations at any database version.

member.summary: Retry commiting a segment of a batch, splitting it in sub-segments as needed

Execute a potentially long read-only operation on batches of elements from a source sequence, using as many transactions as necessary, and automatically scaling the size of each batch to maximize the throughput.
member.typeparam: Type of elements in the source sequence
Type of the local immutable state that is flowed accross all batch operations
member.param: Source database
Source sequence that will be split into batch. The size of each batch will scale up and down automatically depending on the speed of execution
Lambda function that is called once, and returns the initial state that will be passed to the first batch

Retryable lambda function that receives a batch of elements from the source sequence, the current context, and the previous state. If the transaction expires while this lambda function is running, it will be automatically retried with a new transaction, and a smaller batch.
Lambda function that will be called after the last batch, and will be passed the last known state.
Token used to cancel the operation
member.returns: Task that completes when all the elements of have been processed, a non-retryable error occurs, or is triggered

member.name: T:FoundationDB.Client.FdbMutationType
member.summary: Defines a type of mutation applied to a key

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbMutationType.Invalid
member.summary: Invalid

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbMutationType.Add
member.summary: Performs an addition of little-endian integers. If the existing value in the database is not present or shorter than ``param``, it is first extended to the length of ``param`` with zero bytes. If ``param`` is shorter than the existing value in the database, the existing value is truncated to match the length of ``param``. The integers to be added must be stored in a little-endian representation. They can be signed in two's complement representation or unsigned. You can add to an integer at a known offset in the value by prepending the appropriate number of zero bytes to ``param`` and padding with zero bytes to match the length of the value. However, this offset technique requires that you know the addition will not cause the integer field within the value to overflow.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbMutationType.BitAnd
member.summary: Performs a bitwise ``and`` operation. If the existing value in the database is not present or shorter than ``param``, it is first extended to the length of ``param`` with zero bytes. If ``param`` is shorter than the existing value in the database, the existing value is truncated to match the length of ``param``.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbMutationType.BitOr
member.summary: Performs a bitwise ``or`` operation. If the existing value in the database is not present or shorter than ``param``, it is first extended to the length of ``param`` with zero bytes. If ``param`` is shorter than the existing value in the database, the existing value is truncated to match the length of ``param``.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbMutationType.BitXor
member.summary: Performs a bitwise ``xor`` operation. If the existing value in the database is not present or shorter than ``param``, it is first extended to the length of ``param`` with zero bytes. If ``param`` is shorter than the existing value in the database, the existing value is truncated to match the length of ``param``.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransaction.GetAddressesForKeyAsync(FoundationDB.Client.Slice)
member.summary: Returns a list of public network addresses as strings, one for each of the storage servers responsible for storing and its associated value
member.param: Name of the key whose location is to be queried.
member.returns: Task that will return an array of strings, or an exception

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransaction.CommitAsync
member.summary: Attempts to commit the sets and clears previously applied to the database snapshot represented by this transaction to the actual database. The commit may or may not succeed in particular, if a conflicting transaction previously committed, then the commit must fail in order to preserve transactional isolation. If the commit does succeed, the transaction is durably committed to the database and all subsequently started transactions will observe its effects.
member.returns: Task that succeeds if the transaction was comitted successfully, or fails if the transaction failed to commit.
member.remarks: As with other client/server databases, in some failure scenarios a client may be unable to determine whether a transaction succeeded. In these cases, CommitAsync() will throw CommitUnknownResult error. The OnErrorAsync() function treats this error as retryable, so retry loops that dont check for CommitUnknownResult could execute the transaction twice. In these cases, you must consider the idempotence of the transaction.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransaction.Watch(FoundationDB.Client.Slice,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Watch a key for any change in the database.
member.param: Key to watch
CancellationToken used to abort the watch if the caller doesn't want to wait anymore. Note that you can manually cancel the watch by calling Cancel() on the returned FdbWatch instance
member.returns: FdbWatch that can be awaited and will complete when the key has changed in the database, or cancellation occurs. You can call Cancel() at any time if you are not interested in watching the key anymore. You MUST always call Dispose() if the watch completes or is cancelled, to ensure that resources are released properly.
member.remarks: You can directly await an FdbWatch, or obtain a Task<Slice> by reading the property

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransaction.OnErrorAsync(FoundationDB.Client.FdbError)
member.summary:
Implements the recommended retry and backoff behavior for a transaction.
This function knows which of the error codes generated by other query functions represent temporary error conditions and which represent application errors that should be handled by the application. It also implements an exponential backoff strategy to avoid swamping the database cluster with excessive retries when there is a high level of conflict between transactions.
member.param: FdbError code thrown by the previous command
member.returns: Returns a task that completes if the operation can be safely retried, or that rethrows the original exception if the operation is not retryable.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransaction.Cancel

member.name: T:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionExtensions
member.summary: Provides a set of extensions methods shared by all FoundationDB transaction implementations.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionExtensions.WithAccessToSystemKeys``1(``0)
member.summary: Allows this transaction to read and modify system keys (those that start with the byte 0xFF)

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionExtensions.WithPrioritySystemImmediate``1(``0)
member.summary: Specifies that this transaction should be treated as highest priority and that lower priority transactions should block behind this one. Use is discouraged outside of low-level tools

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionExtensions.WithPriorityBatch``1(``0)
member.summary: Specifies that this transaction should be treated as low priority and that default priority transactions should be processed first. Useful for doing batch work simultaneously with latency-sensitive work

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionExtensions.WithReadYourWritesDisable``1(``0)
member.summary: Reads performed by a transaction will not see any prior mutations that occurred in that transaction, instead seeing the value which was in the database at the transaction's read version. This option may provide a small performance benefit for the client, but also disables a number of client-side optimizations which are beneficial for transactions which tend to read and write the same keys within a single transaction. Also note that with this option invoked any outstanding reads will return errors when transaction commit is called (rather than the normal behavior of commit waiting for outstanding reads to complete).

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionExtensions.WithReadAheadDisable``1(``0)
member.summary: Disables read-ahead caching for range reads. Under normal operation, a transaction will read extra rows from the database into cache if range reads are used to page through a series of data one row at a time (i.e. if a range read with a one row limit is followed by another one row range read starting immediately after the result of the first).

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionExtensions.WithNextWriteNoWriteConflictRange``1(``0)
member.summary: The next write performed on this transaction will not generate a write conflict range. As a result, other transactions which read the key(s) being modified by the next write will not conflict with this transaction. Care needs to be taken when using this option on a transaction that is shared between multiple threads. When setting this option, write conflict ranges will be disabled on the next write operation, regardless of what thread it is on.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionExtensions.WithTimeout``1(``0,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Set a timeout in milliseconds which, when elapsed, will cause the transaction automatically to be cancelled. Valid parameter values are ``[0, INT_MAX]``. If set to 0, will disable all timeouts. All pending and any future uses of the transaction will throw an exception. The transaction can be used again after it is reset.
member.param: Timeout (with millisecond precision), or TimeSpan.Zero for infinite timeout

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionExtensions.WithTimeout``1(``0,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set a timeout in milliseconds which, when elapsed, will cause the transaction automatically to be cancelled. Valid parameter values are ``[0, INT_MAX]``. If set to 0, will disable all timeouts. All pending and any future uses of the transaction will throw an exception. The transaction can be used again after it is reset.
member.param: Timeout in millisecond, or 0 for infinite timeout

member.summary: Set a maximum number of retries after which additional calls to onError will throw the most recently seen error code. Valid parameter values are ``[-1, INT_MAX]``. If set to -1, will disable the retry limit.

member.name: M:FoundationDB.Client.FdbKey.PrettyPrint(FoundationDB.Client.Slice,FoundationDB.Client.FdbKey.PrettyPrintMode)
member.summary: Produce a user-friendly version of the slice
member.param: Random binary key
Defines if the key is standalone, or is the begin or end part or a key range. This will enable or disable some heuristics that try to properly format key ranges.
member.returns: User friendly version of the key. Attempts to decode the key as a tuple first. Then as an ASCII string. Then as an hex dump of the key.
member.remarks: This can be slow, and should only be used for logging or troubleshooting.

member.name: T:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption
member.summary: Defines a set of options for a transaction

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.CausalWriteRisky
member.summary: The transaction, if not self-conflicting, may be committed a second time after commit succeeds, in the event of a fault Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.CausalReadRisky
member.summary: The read version will be committed, and usually will be the latest committed, but might not be the latest committed in the event of a fault or partition Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.CausalReadDisable
member.summary: Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.NextWriteNoWriteConflictRange
member.summary: The next write performed on this transaction will not generate a write conflict range. As a result, other transactions which read the key(s) being modified by the next write will not conflict with this transaction. Care needs to be taken when using this option on a transaction that is shared between multiple threads. When setting this option, write conflict ranges will be disabled on the next write operation, regardless of what thread it is on. Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.CheckWritesEnable
member.summary: Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.ReadYourWritesDisable
member.summary: Reads performed by a transaction will not see any prior mutations that occurred in that transaction, instead seeing the value which was in the database at the transaction's read version. This option may provide a small performance benefit for the client, but also disables a number of client-side optimizations which are beneficial for transactions which tend to read and write the same keys within a single transaction. Also note that with this option invoked any outstanding reads will return errors when transaction commit is called (rather than the normal behavior of commit waiting for outstanding reads to complete). Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.ReadAheadDisable
member.summary: Disables read-ahead caching for range reads. Under normal operation, a transaction will read extra rows from the database into cache if range reads are used to page through a series of data one row at a time (i.e. if a range read with a one row limit is followed by another one row range read starting immediately after the result of the first). Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.DurabilityDataCenter
member.summary: Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.DurabilityRisky
member.summary: Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.DevNullIsWebScale
member.summary: Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.PrioritySystemImmediate
member.summary: Specifies that this transaction should be treated as highest priority and that lower priority transactions should block behind this one. Use is discouraged outside of low-level tools Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.PriorityBatch
member.summary: Specifies that this transaction should be treated as low priority and that default priority transactions should be processed first. Useful for doing batch work simultaneously with latency-sensitive work Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.InitializeNewDatabase
member.summary: This is a write-only transaction which sets the initial configuration Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.AccessSystemKeys
member.summary: Allows this transaction to read and modify system keys (those that start with the byte 0xFF) Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.DebugDump
member.summary: Parameter: Option takes no parameter

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.Timeout
member.summary: Set a timeout in milliseconds which, when elapsed, will cause the transaction automatically to be cancelled. Valid parameter values are ``[0, INT_MAX]``. If set to 0, will disable all timeouts. All pending and any future uses of the transaction will throw an exception. The transaction can be used again after it is reset. Parameter: (Int) value in milliseconds of timeout

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbTransactionOption.RetryLimit
member.summary: Set a maximum number of retries after which additional calls to onError will throw the most recently seen error code. Valid parameter values are ``[-1, INT_MAX]``. If set to -1, will disable the retry limit. Parameter: (Int) number of times to retry

member.name: T:FoundationDB.Client.FdbDatabaseOption
member.summary: Defines a set of options for the database connection

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbDatabaseOption.None
member.summary: No option defined

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbDatabaseOption.LocationCacheSize
member.summary: Set the size of the client location cache. Raising this value can boost performance in very large databases where clients access data in a near-random pattern. Defaults to 100000. Parameter: (Int) Max location cache entries

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbDatabaseOption.MaxWatches
member.summary: Set the maximum number of watches allowed to be outstanding on a database connection. Increasing this number could result in increased resource usage. Reducing this number will not cancel any outstanding watches. Defaults to 10000 and cannot be larger than 1000000. Parameter: (Int) Max outstanding watches

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbDatabaseOption.MachineId
member.summary: Specify the machine ID that was passed to fdbserver processes running on the same machine as this client, for better location-aware load balancing. Parameter: (String) Hexadecimal ID

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbDatabaseOption.DataCenterId
member.summary: Specify the datacenter ID that was passed to fdbserver processes running in the same datacenter as this client, for better location-aware load balancing. Parameter: (String) Hexadecimal ID

member.name: T:FoundationDB.Client.FdbStreamingMode
member.summary: Defines how the client would like the data in a range a returned

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbStreamingMode.WantAll
member.summary: Client intends to consume the entire range and would like it all transferred as early as possible.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbStreamingMode.Iterator
member.summary: The default. The client doesn't know how much of the range it is likely to used and wants different performance concerns to be balanced. Only a small portion of data is transferred to the client initially (in order to minimize costs if the client doesn't read the entire range), and as the caller iterates over more items in the range larger batches will be transferred in order to minimize latency.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbStreamingMode.Exact
member.summary: Infrequently used. The client has passed a specific row limit and wants that many rows delivered in a single batch. Because of iterator operation in client drivers make request batches transparent to the user, consider WANT_ALL StreamingMode instead. A row limit must be specified if this mode is used.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbStreamingMode.Small
member.summary: Infrequently used. Transfer data in batches small enough to not be much more expensive than reading individual rows, to minimize cost if iteration stops early.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbStreamingMode.Medium
member.summary: Infrequently used. Transfer data in batches sized in between small and large. Usually the default

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbStreamingMode.Large
member.summary: Infrequently used. Transfer data in batches large enough to be, in a high-concurrency environment, nearly as efficient as possible. If the client stops iteration early, some disk and network bandwidth may be wasted. The batch size may still be too small to allow a single client to get high throughput from the database, so if that is what you need consider the SERIAL StreamingMode.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Client.FdbStreamingMode.Serial
member.summary: Transfer data in batches large enough that an individual client can get reasonable read bandwidth from the database. If the client stops iteration early, considerable disk and network bandwidth may be wasted.

member.name: T:FoundationDB.Layers.Directories.FdbDirectoryLayer
member.summary: Provides a FdbDirectoryLayer class for managing directories in FoundationDB. Directories are a recommended approach for administering layers and applications. Directories work in conjunction with subspaces. Each layer or application should create or open at least one directory with which to manage its subspace(s). Directories are identified by paths (specified as tuples) analogous to the paths in a Unix-like file system. Each directory has an associated subspace that is used to store content. The layer uses a high-contention allocator to efficiently map each path to a short prefix for its corresponding subspace. exposes methods to create, open, move, remove, or list directories. Creating or opening a directory returns the corresponding subspace. The class represents subspaces that store the contents of a directory. An instance of can be used for all the usual subspace operations. It can also be used to operate on the directory with which it was opened.

member.summary: Create a range that selects all the tuples of greater length than the specified , and that start with the specified elements: packed(tuple)+'\x00' <= k < packed(tuple)+'\xFF'
member.example: FdbTuple.ToRange(FdbTuple.Create("a", "b")) includes all tuples ("a", "b", ...), but not the tuple ("a", "b") itself.

member.name: T:FoundationDB.Linq.FdbAsyncMode
member.summary: Defines the intent of a consumer of an async iterator

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Linq.FdbAsyncMode.Default
member.summary: Use the default settings. The provider will make no attempt at optimizing the query.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Linq.FdbAsyncMode.Iterator
member.summary: The query will be consumed by chunks and may be aborted at any point. The provider will produce small chunks of data for the first few reads but should still be efficient if the caller consume all the sequence.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Linq.FdbAsyncMode.All
member.summary: The query will consume all the items in the source. The provider will produce large chunks of data immediately, and reduce the number of pages needed to consume the sequence.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Linq.FdbAsyncMode.Head
member.summary: The query will consume the first element (or a very small fraction) of the source. The provider will only produce data in small chunks and expect the caller to abort after one or two iterations. This can also be used to reduce the latency of the first result.

member.name: F:FoundationDB.Linq.FdbAsyncMode.Bulk
member.summary: The query will consume all (or most of) the items of a very large sequence of data. The provider will use the appropriate page size in ordre to optimize the bandwith.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the methos doesn't return normally.
canbenull annotation is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // regular assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("s:null=>false; =>true,result:notnull; =>false, result:null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.CannotApplyEqualityOperatorAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that the value of the marked type (or its derivatives) cannot be compared using '==' or '!=' operators and Equals() should be used instead. However, using '==' or '!=' for comparison with null is always permitted.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.InstantHandleAttribute
member.summary: Tells code analysis engine if the parameter is completely handled when the invoked method is on stack. If the parameter is a delegate, indicates that delegate is executed while the method is executed. If the parameter is an enumerable, indicates that it is enumerated while the method is executed

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.PureAttribute
member.summary: Indicates that a method does not make any observable state changes. The same as System.Diagnostics.Contracts.PureAttribute

member.summary: Lexicographically compare this slice with another one, and return an indication of their relative sort order
member.param: Slice to compare with this instance
member.returns: Returns a NEGATIVE value if the current slice is LESS THAN , ZERO if it is EQUAL TO , and a POSITIVE value if it is GREATER THAN .
member.remarks: If both this instance and are Nil or Empty, the comparison will return ZERO. If only is Nil or Empty, it will return a NEGATIVE value. If only this instance is Nil or Empty, it will return a POSITIVE value.

member.param: New size of the buffer

member.param: Number of bytes to remove at the head of the buffer

member.remarks: This should be called after every successfull write to the underlying stream, to update the buffer.
